summary: A cybersecurity and case management system website with high-quality UI and graphics, intended as a 6th semester project.
architectural_notes: Web-based application targeting modern browsers with responsive design
Focus on cybersecurity domain: threat monitoring, incident management, and case tracking

existing_features.title: Design and implement a visually striking dark-themed UI with a cyberpunk/tech aesthetic: deep dark backgrounds (#0a0f1e, #0d1b2a), neon accent colors (electric green #00ff88, cyan #00d4ff), glowing effects, animated grid backgrounds, and sharp modern typography (monospace for data, sans-serif for headings). Apply this theme consistently across all pages and components.

Implement Internet Identity authentication so users can securely log in. After login, distinguish between two roles: Admin and Analyst. Display the current user's role and identity in the navigation bar.

Build a cybersecurity threat monitoring dashboard as the main landing page after login. Display: total active threats, resolved incidents, open cases, and system health status as animated stat cards. Include a live threat feed list showing recent incidents with severity badges (Critical, High, Medium, Low). Add a bar or line chart showing incident trends over the last 7 days using mock/static data.

Build a Case Management page with a full-featured case list table. Include columns for Case ID, Title, Severity badge, Status badge, Assigned Analyst, and Created Date. Add filter controls for severity and status. Provide a modal form to create a new case. Each row should have action buttons to view details, update status, and (for Admins) delete.

Build a Case Detail page accessible by clicking a case row. Show all case fields, a status timeline/history section, and a notes/comments section where analysts can add free-text notes. Store notes in the backend as an array of { author, timestamp, content } within the case record.

Implement an Incident Reporting page with a structured form to log new security incidents. Fields: Incident Title, Type (Phishing / Malware / DDoS / Data Breach / Unauthorized Access / Other), Description, Affected Systems (text), Severity, and Reporter Name. On submission, auto-create a corresponding case in the backend. Display a log of all submitted incident reports in a table below the form.

Add a responsive navigation sidebar with links to: Dashboard, Cases, Incident Reports, Analytics, and (for Admins) User Management. The sidebar should collapse to an icon-only mode on smaller screens. Include an app logo with the CyberShield name and an animated status indicator showing 'System Secure' or 'Threats Detected' based on open critical cases.

Build an Analytics page with visual charts summarizing case data. Include: a donut/pie chart for case distribution by severity, a bar chart for cases by type/category, and a status summary showing counts of Open vs In Progress vs Resolved cases. Use animated chart components. All data must be derived from cases stored in the backend.
Create and integrate the following visual assets: a futuristic cybersecurity hero banner for the login/landing page, an app logo mark for the sidebar, and a background texture for dashboard cards.

Update the frontend login and profile setup flow to enforce role-specific access. After Internet Identity login, call getMyProfile() to check if the user has a profile. If not, show the ProfileSetupModal to register. After profile setup or if profile exists, redirect based on role: both Admin and Analyst land on the dashboard, but Admin-only sections (User Management, delete/assign case actions) must be hidden or disabled for Analyst role. Show the user's role label and display name in the navigation header and sidebar.

Update all frontend React Query hooks in useQueries.ts to call the real backend actor functions instead of mock data: useGetAllCases, useGetCaseById, useCreateCase, useUpdateCaseStatus, useAddNoteToCase, useAssignCase, useDeleteCase, useGetAllIncidentReports, useSubmitIncidentReport, useGetMyProfile, and useRegisterUser. Ensure proper cache invalidation on mutations.

Add a User Management page accessible only to Admin users. Display a table of all registered users showing their principal (truncated), display name, and role. Provide a role toggle control per row allowing Admins to switch a user between Analyst and Admin roles by calling the setUserRole backend function. Show a confirmation prompt before changing roles.

new_feature_requests.summary: Cybersecurity dashboard with threat monitoring and analytics
Case management system with case creation, tracking, and resolution workflows
High-quality UI with modern graphics, animations, and visual design
User authentication and role-based access control

Implement a backend data model for cybersecurity cases. Each case must store: unique ID, title, description, severity (Critical/High/Medium/Low), status (Open/In Progress/Resolved/Closed), assigned analyst principal, reporter principal, creation timestamp, and last updated timestamp. Persist all cases in stable backend storage.

Expose backend query and update functions for case management: createCase, getAllCases, getCaseById, updateCaseStatus, assignCase, and deleteCase. Only Admin principals can delete or assign cases; Analysts can create and update status.

Implement a complete backend data model in main.mo with stable storage for: User profiles (principal, name, role as #admin or #analyst, createdAt), Cases (unique ID, title, description, severity variant, status variant, assignedAnalyst principal, reporterPrincipal, createdAt, updatedAt, notes array of {author, timestamp, content}), and Incident Reports (unique ID, title, type, description, affectedSystems, severity, reporterName, linkedCaseId, createdAt). Use stable var arrays or HashMap with stable backup for persistence across upgrades.

Implement role-based access control in the backend. Maintain a stable registry mapping principal to role (#admin or #analyst). Expose a registerUser(name: Text) function for first-time profile setup that assigns #analyst by default. Expose a setUserRole(target: Principal, role: Role) function callable only by Admin principals. Expose a getMyProfile() query that returns the caller's profile. The first registered user should automatically receive the #admin role.

Expose full CRUD backend functions for case management: createCase(title, description, severity, type) callable by both Admin and Analyst; getAllCases() query returning all cases; getCaseById(id) query; updateCaseStatus(id, newStatus) callable by Admin and Analyst; addNoteToCase(id, content) callable by Admin and Analyst (stores {author: caller principal text, timestamp, content}); assignCase(id, analystPrincipal) callable by Admin only; deleteCase(id) callable by Admin only. All mutating functions must verify caller identity and role before proceeding.

Expose backend functions for incident report management: submitIncidentReport(title, type, description, affectedSystems, severity, reporterName) callable by any authenticated user — this must also auto-create a linked case and return both the incident report ID and the new case ID; getAllIncidentReports() query returning all reports; getIncidentReportById(id) query.

Implement a complete backend data model in main.mo with stable storage for: User profiles (principal, displayName, role as #admin or #analyst, createdAt), Cases (unique ID, title, description, severity variant (#critical | #high | #medium | #low), status variant (#open | #inProgress | #resolved | #closed), assignedAnalyst as ?Principal, reporterPrincipal, createdAt, updatedAt, notes array of { author: Text, timestamp: Int, content: Text }, caseType: Text), and Incident Reports (unique ID, title, incidentType, description, affectedSystems, severity, reporterName, linkedCaseId: ?Text, createdAt). Use stable var arrays or HashMap with stable backup for persistence across upgrades.

Implement role-based access control in the backend. Maintain a stable registry mapping Principal to UserProfile. Expose registerUser(name: Text) for first-time profile setup — assigns #analyst by default, but the very first registered user automatically receives #admin. Expose setUserRole(target: Principal, role: Role) callable only by Admin principals. Expose getMyProfile() query returning the caller's profile as ?UserProfile. Expose getAllUsers() query callable by Admin only, returning all profiles.

Expose full CRUD backend functions for case management: createCase(title: Text, description: Text, severity: Severity, caseType: Text) callable by any authenticated registered user; getAllCases() query returning all cases; getCaseById(id: Text) query returning ?Case; updateCaseStatus(id: Text, newStatus: Status) callable by Admin and Analyst; addNoteToCase(id: Text, content: Text) callable by Admin and Analyst, storing { author: Principal-as-Text, timestamp: Int, content: Text }; assignCase(id: Text, analystPrincipal: Principal) callable by Admin only; deleteCase(id: Text) callable by Admin only. All mutating functions must verify caller identity and role before proceeding.

Expose backend functions for incident report management: submitIncidentReport(title: Text, incidentType: Text, description: Text, affectedSystems: Text, severity: Severity, reporterName: Text) callable by any authenticated registered user — this must also auto-create a linked Case and return a record containing both the new incident report ID and the linked case ID; getAllIncidentReports() query returning all reports; getIncidentReportById(id: Text) query returning ?IncidentReport.
